Command. Result set management. This command allows for a variety of operations on result sets.
See also: results

Results are static sets of output from a search that are named and may be queried separately. Creation and management ----------------------- You create them in searches using the -rs name flag, e.g.
admins> search >admin_id -r .*caltech.* -rs ligo
would search (in the admins store) the property name admin_id for any entry including the string "calttech" and stash the results in a result set named "ligo". You may now use the rs command to navigate this result set. You may have as many result sets as you like.
You may also restrict the results to a subset of properties with the -attr flag.
admins> search >admin_id -attr [allow_qdl,name] -r .*caltech.* -rs qdl_check
would search on the admin_id and the result set would have the two properties listed. Showing the result set then only has those.
admins>rs list foo foo: 56 entries, fields=[allow_qdl, name]
admins> rs show [11,17] foo 11. true | Test admin client caltech-IGWN 12. true | Test admin client caltech/LIGO 13. false | IGWN admin for VIRGO 1 14. true | IGWN admin for VIRGO 2 15. true | LIGO issuer UW Milwaukee 16. true | LIGO issuer UW Madison
shows the subset from index 11 in the list up to but not including index 17 (or the end of the list, whichever comes first).
The -show flag also allows for displaying subsets but be warned that if you searched for a subset of properties, then only those are available. You may restrict to a subset of those, but cannot display properties you do not have.
Result sets as arguments ------------------------ Most commands allow you to specify a result set or subset as an argument. The basic syntax is -rs name (-- | -range) (list | integer) where name is the name and the range is either a single integer giving the index in the set or a list of them. Be aware that some commands only accept a single object (e.g. changing and id, which would give multiple objects the same id.)
Lists ----- Lists are actually valid QDL, though are restricted to being un-nested. You could therefore list the elements of a result set named X from 1 through 6 as
rs show -range [1;7] X
Negative indices are allowed, which reference element from the end of the set
rs show -range -1 X
references the last element of the set X.
Similarly you could do a mass update as
update >debug_on -value false -rs X
would set the debug_on flag to false for every element in X
Caveat: Result sets are static! This means that an update will update the stored objects that the result set references. If you alter the stored object(s) you will need to refresh your result set accordingly.

Command. Search the store, You may search on a given property and may do so in several ways. Consult the online help for this, in particular the --ex (note the double hyphen) option will print many examples.
Command. The number of entries in the store.
Command. A wide-ranging command that allows you to update an entire object, prompting you for each property, or update a specific property.
The current version of OA4MP is 6.x-SNAPSHOT.

index - Supports a set id (from set_id), the index from a listing, an explicit identifier, or a result set. If present it is always the last argument. You may get an index by 1. using the set_id command to set it globally. The index is then optional. 2. Explicitly give the unique identifier. 3. You may use the name of a result set. You may also restrict the elements used (see below). 4. IF you have listed the entire contents with ls, you may give the numeric index of the object How to specify the range of indices used in a result set. ( -range | -- ) (integer | list | iterator) Examples of ranges are: 5 (integer), [2,4,5] (a list), [2;7] integers from to through 6 inclusive. Negative indices are allowed and mean to take from the end of the list, so my_command -- -1 my_set returns the last element in the result set name my_set. Note that while you may specify arguments this way, result sets are static and operations will be carried out on the actual stored object.
For operations on result sets proper, see --help for the rs command.

Note on QDL lists, All of the keys for the current store are put into QDL, assigning their name to the value, so you do not need to quote those. If there are lists, you may use arbitrary expressions. Now, since OA4MP needs a way to find the end of such statments (a thorny general parsing problem), just mark the end using the end of expression marker, ^^. E.g.
rs show -attr [ 'client_' + 'id' , 'desc' + 'ription' ] ^^ c842
would send the entire list to QDL. In such cases you are writing QDL which is often overkill. However, in conjunction with run_qdl, you may have arbitrarily complex statements for lists. Note that if you should terminate every list statement with ^^ if you do any. For the vast majority of lists, just use simple syntax, E.g. rs show -attr [client_id,description] c842

You may set the id for this store for every operation that requires one using an index. This means that if your command is, say, serialize, the following are equivalent
Note that if you set this, it overrides any argument you may give it as the index. Case 1: Direct cli>serialize my:unique:id (output)
Case 2: Set the working id for the store cli>set_id my:unique:id cli>serialize (output)
See also: index, clear_id, get_id
